name: Zimbabwe
takeaway: Zimbabwe's current relations with the PRC were prompted by the ejection of Zimbabwe from the Commonwealth & imposition of targeted sanctions on elites. Official accounts of gains from Zimbabwe-China relations are challenged by the generality of citizens who see them as narrowly benefiting PRC & Zimbabwe elites.
China's activities in Zimbabwe are viewed by ordinary citizens as motivated by imperial & political interests over human rights.
China's influence on Zimbabwe is being exerted by both soft and hard power.

PRC technologies and many goods are seen as cheap & non-durable by the generality of Zimbabweans. Most Zimbabweans think they can only benefit from relations with PRC if the latter is to genuinely focus on the revival & growth of Zimbabwe's manufacturing sector.

While Zimbabwe's government controlled media parrots PRC culture, PRC's mainstream media does not have much interest in Zimbabwe's cultural well-being. Emerging cultural relations between Zimbabwe & PRC are asymetrical, with the latter being more interested in championing its economic interests.
description-1: In 2023, Zimbabwe had a GDP per capita of US$1,592 and a total population of 16.20 million people.
description-2: Zimbabwe established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1980. Zimbabwe was ranked 116th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Not Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 27/100.

Media.evidence: There are several media outlets with links to World Chinese Media Networks in Zimbabwe.Xinhua journalists are accredited to practice journalism in Zimbabwe. They normally have Zimbabwean citizens working as their correspondents in Zimbabwe | The Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC) and CCTV signed a memorandum of understanding that saw ZBC broadcasting CCTV’s news programmes for three years from 2012, and as of 2023, ZBC signed an MOU with Xinhua for media cooperation and sharing broadcast content.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Review and mail as well as the Xinhua news agency are Chinese owned
Media.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Journalists from Zimbabwe have gone to China for exchange programs and some have won awards in writing about China.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: There are reports of journalists from state-owned media such as The Herald and Zimbabwe Broadcasting Cooperation who have received some form of training in PRC.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
Media.answerer: Answered by 3 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Although China has supported local government-owned media with donations of equipment and training of journalists, there's no evidence of ownership of the media
Media.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: ZBC is broadcasting content from China news network on PRC culture.

Media.evidence: Chinese companies and the PRC advertise on ZBC as well as state media on projects by Chinese entities like Sino Cement.

Media.evidence: Chinese Embassy issued a statement condemning and threatening the private media exposing unfair labour practises by the Chenese in Zimbabwe.

Media.evidence:
State-owned newspapers like The Herald and public broadcaster, the Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation uses the emotive language to refer to Zimbabwe's relations with the PRC.                                         
They refer to PRC as all-weather friend

Media.evidence: Some journalists and academics from state-owned institutions have published articles in state media denying the existence of human rights abuses in the PRC.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Zimbabwe and China have many areas of cooperation and the PRC has built a parliament building for Zimbabwe

Foreign Policy.evidence: Zimbabwe receives foreign aid and in-kind donations from the PRC including humanitarian assistance and donations to the ruling party in Zimbabwe.The country has received Covid vaccines, the new parliament building, central medical stores as donations just to mention but a few

Foreign Policy.evidence: Zimbabwe and China have many areas of cooperation and they classify their relationship as Strategic Partnership. In 2018, the two countries agreed to establish comprehensive strategic partnership of cooperation. China has vetoed UN security council resolutions on imposing sanctions on Zimbabwe as a result of the partnership.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Zimbabwe consistently uses PRC's one China principle.

Economy.evidence: China is Zimbabwe's second biggest trading partner. South Africa is no. 1.

Economy.evidence: China holds below 15 per cent of Zimbabwe's debt

Economy.evidence: The PRC is Zimbabwe's fourth largest customer of extractive minerals. The PRC has a 4% share of Zimbabwe's total exports.

Economy.evidence: PRC related entities like Sinomines, Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt, and Chengxin Lithium Group have controlling shareholdings in the biggest mines.Other major businesses like Anjin Investments are jointly owned by an Anhui firm and the Zimbabwean army. Similarly, Chinese large enterprises have invested in local lithium mines.

Military.evidence:

https://www.prio.org/publications/13209
